resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

wesm commented on pull request #3567: WIP ARROW-4446: [C++][Python] Run Gandiva C++ unit tests in Appveyor, get build and tests working in Python
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3567
 
 
   This works for me locally. It's WIP because there's a single C++ failure in Appveyor that may be locale-specific
   
   There's a number of other fixes in here. I'll list all the JIRA issues that this patch will resolve in due course

wesm commented on issue #3567: WIP ARROW-4446: [C++][Python] Run Gandiva C++ unit tests in Appveyor, get build and tests working in Python
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3567#issuecomment-460819263
 
 
   @pravindra @praveenbingo let me know if you know how to resolve this failure; seems there is an unhandled failure mode here of some kind
   
   ```
   Running main() from gmock_main.cc
   [==========] Running 8 tests from 1 test case.
   [----------] Global test environment set-up.
   [----------] 8 tests from TestTime
   [ RUN      ] TestTime.TestCastDate
   [       OK ] TestTime.TestCastDate (1 ms)
   [ RUN      ] TestTime.TestCastTimestamp
   C:\projects\arrow\cpp\src\gandiva\precompiled\time_test.cc(72): error:       Expected: castTIMESTAMP_utf8(context_ptr, "2000-09-23 9:45:30.920 Canada/Pacific", 37)
         Which is: 0
   To be equal to: 969727530920
   C:\projects\arrow\cpp\src\gandiva\precompiled\time_test.cc(74): error:       Expected: castTIMESTAMP_utf8(context_ptr, "2012-02-28 23:30:59 Asia/Kolkata", 32)
         Which is: 0
   To be equal to: 1330452059000
   C:\projects\arrow\cpp\src\gandiva\precompiled\time_test.cc(76): error:       Expected: castTIMESTAMP_utf8(context_ptr, "1923-10-07 03:03:03 America/New_York", 36)
         Which is: 0
   To be equal to: -1459094217000
   C:\projects\arrow\cpp\src\gandiva\precompiled\time_test.cc(80): error:       Expected: context.get_error()
         Which is: "Invalid timestamp or unknown zone for timestamp value 2000-09-23 9:45:30.920 Canada/Pacific"
   To be equal to: "Not a valid day for timestamp value 20000923"
   [  FAILED  ] TestTime.TestCastTimestamp (2 ms)
   [ RUN      ] TestTime.TestExtractTime
   [       OK ] TestTime.TestExtractTime (0 ms)
   [ RUN      ] TestTime.TestExtractTimestamp
   [       OK ] TestTime.TestExtractTimestamp (0 ms)
   [ RUN      ] TestTime.TimeStampTrunc
   [       OK ] TestTime.TimeStampTrunc (1 ms)
   [ RUN      ] TestTime.TimeStampAdd
   [       OK ] TestTime.TimeStampAdd (0 ms)
   [ RUN      ] TestTime.TestExtractWeek
   [       OK ] TestTime.TestExtractWeek (2 ms)
   [ RUN      ] TestTime.TestMonthsBetween
   [       OK ] TestTime.TestMonthsBetween (0 ms)
   [----------] 8 tests from TestTime (6 ms total)
   [----------] Global test environment tear-down
   [==========] 8 tests from 1 test case ran. (6 ms total)
   [  PASSED  ] 7 tests.
   [  FAILED  ] 1 test, listed below:
   [  FAILED  ] TestTime.TestCastTimestamp
    1 FAILED TEST
   ```

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3567#issuecomment-460912035
 
 
   > @pravindra @praveenbingo let me know if you know how to resolve this failure; seems there is an unhandled failure mode here of some kind
   > 
   > ```
   > Running main() from gmock_main.cc
   > [==========] Running 8 tests from 1 test case.
   > [----------] Global test environment set-up.
   > [----------] 8 tests from TestTime
   > [ RUN      ] TestTime.TestCastDate
   > [       OK ] TestTime.TestCastDate (1 ms)
   > [ RUN      ] TestTime.TestCastTimestamp
   > C:\projects\arrow\cpp\src\gandiva\precompiled\time_test.cc(72): error:       Expected: castTIMESTAMP_utf8(context_ptr, "2000-09-23 9:45:30.920 Canada/Pacific", 37)
   >       Which is: 0
   > To be equal to: 969727530920
   > C:\projects\arrow\cpp\src\gandiva\precompiled\time_test.cc(74): error:       Expected: castTIMESTAMP_utf8(context_ptr, "2012-02-28 23:30:59 Asia/Kolkata", 32)
   >       Which is: 0
   > To be equal to: 1330452059000
   > C:\projects\arrow\cpp\src\gandiva\precompiled\time_test.cc(76): error:       Expected: castTIMESTAMP_utf8(context_ptr, "1923-10-07 03:03:03 America/New_York", 36)
   >       Which is: 0
   > To be equal to: -1459094217000
   > C:\projects\arrow\cpp\src\gandiva\precompiled\time_test.cc(80): error:       Expected: context.get_error()
   >       Which is: "Invalid timestamp or unknown zone for timestamp value 2000-09-23 9:45:30.920 Canada/Pacific"
   > To be equal to: "Not a valid day for timestamp value 20000923"
   > [  FAILED  ] TestTime.TestCastTimestamp (2 ms)
   > [ RUN      ] TestTime.TestExtractTime
   > [       OK ] TestTime.TestExtractTime (0 ms)
   > [ RUN      ] TestTime.TestExtractTimestamp
   > [       OK ] TestTime.TestExtractTimestamp (0 ms)
   > [ RUN      ] TestTime.TimeStampTrunc
   > [       OK ] TestTime.TimeStampTrunc (1 ms)
   > [ RUN      ] TestTime.TimeStampAdd
   > [       OK ] TestTime.TimeStampAdd (0 ms)
   > [ RUN      ] TestTime.TestExtractWeek
   > [       OK ] TestTime.TestExtractWeek (2 ms)
   > [ RUN      ] TestTime.TestMonthsBetween
   > [       OK ] TestTime.TestMonthsBetween (0 ms)
   > [----------] 8 tests from TestTime (6 ms total)
   > [----------] Global test environment tear-down
   > [==========] 8 tests from 1 test case ran. (6 ms total)
   > [  PASSED  ] 7 tests.
   > [  FAILED  ] 1 test, listed below:
   > [  FAILED  ] TestTime.TestCastTimestamp
   >  1 FAILED TEST
   > ```
   
   I remember @shyambits2004 mentioning that the date library uses some system database to map the timezone name to a displacement value. Likely the database isn't present on windows or it's using a wrong path name.

fields.summary: [Python] Run Gandiva tests on Windows and Appveyor

comments.body:
For the timezone implementation, we are using the operating systems timezone database. For windows, the expectation is IANA database is downloaded into the required location as specified below.

REF : [https://howardhinnant.github.io/date/tz.html]

1. USE_OS_TZDB : If {{USE_OS_TZDB}} is {{1}} then this library will use the zic-compiled time zone database provided by your OS. This option relieves you of having to install the IANA time zone database, either manually, or automatically with {{AUTO_DOWNLOAD}}. This option is not available on Windows.

2. If the macro {{INSTALL}} is not defined, the default location of the database is {{~/Downloads/tzdata}}({{%homedrive%\%homepath%\downloads\tzdata}} on Windows).

3. On Windows, {{HAS_REMOTE_API}} defaults to {{0}}. Everywhere else it defaults to {{1}}. This is because [{{libcurl}}|https://curl.haxx.se/libcurl/] comes preinstalled everywhere but Windows, but it is available for Windows.

4. If you want to enable {{HAS_REMOTE_API}} and/or {{AUTO_DOWNLOAD}} on Windows you will have to manually install [curl|https://curl.haxx.se/libcurl/] and [7-zip|http://www.7-zip.org/] into their default locations.

5. If you do not enable {{HAS_REMOTE_API}}, you will need to also install [http://unicode.org/repos/cldr/trunk/common/supplemental/windowsZones.xml] into your {{install}} location. This will be done for you if you have enabled {{HAS_REMOTE_API}} and let {{AUTO_DOWNLOAD}} default to 1.
[~shyamsingh] can you open a new Jira for fixing the date/tz issue on windows ? Till that's fixed, we could disable the test on windows.
